{{Use British English|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = William Grover-Williams | image = William Grover-Williams at the 1931 Grand Prix de Belgique.jpg | caption = William Grover-Williams as the winner of the [[1931 Belgian Grand Prix]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1903|1|16|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Montrouge]], [[Hauts-de-Seine]], [[French Third Republic|France]] | death_date = February or March, 1945 (aged 42) | death_place = [[Sachsenhausen concentration camp]], [[Nazi Germany]] | occupation = Racing driver
[[Special Operations Executive|SOE]] agent | spouse = {{marriage|Yvonne Aupicq |1929|1945}} | parents = Frederick Grover
Hermance Dagan }} '''William Charles Frederick Grover-Williams''' (born '''William Charles Frederick Grover''', 16 January 1903 – February or March 1945),{{cite book |last=Saward |authorlink=Joe Saward|title=The Grand Prix Saboteurs|pages=27, 317–318}} also known as '''"W Williams"''', was a [[Grand Prix motor racing]] driver and special agent who worked for the [[Special Operations Executive]] (SOE) inside [[France]]. He organised and coordinated the ''[[SOE F Section networks#Chestnut|Chestnut]]'' network. He was captured and executed by the [[Nazism|Nazis]]. ==Personal and early life== Grover-Williams was born in [[Montrouge]], [[Hauts-de-Seine]], France, on 16 January 1903 to Frederick and Hermance Grover. Frederick Grover was an English [[horse breeding|horse breeder]] who had settled in Montrouge. Frederick met a French girl, Hermance Dagan, and they were soon married. Their first child was Elizabeth, born in 1897. William had two other siblings – Alice and Frederic.{{cite book |last=Saward |authorlink=Joe Saward|title=The Grand Prix Saboteurs|pages=27}} Born to an English father and a French mother, Grover-Williams grew up fluent in both the French and English languages. When William was eleven, he was sent to live with relatives in [[Hertfordshire]], in the [[United Kingdom]]. After the war, Frederick Grover moved the family to [[Monte Carlo]]. It was there that William developed a fascination for automobiles, having been taught to drive a [[Rolls-Royce Limited|Rolls-Royce]] by his sister's boyfriend. Grover-Williams passed his [[driving test]] whilst in [[Monaco]] and was granted a [[Driver's license|licence]].{{cite book |last=Saward |authorlink=Joe Saward|title=The Grand Prix Saboteurs|pages=28}} Mechanically inclined, and fascinated by motorised vehicles, at the age of 15, Grover-Williams acquired an [[Indian (motorcycle)|Indian]] motorcycle and it became his pride and joy.{{cite book |last=Saward |authorlink=Joe Saward|title=The Grand Prix Saboteurs|pages=29}} He would later go on to compete in motorcycle races in the early 1920s, although he kept it secret from his family by adopting the pseudonym, "W Williams".{{cite book |last=Saward |authorlink=Joe Saward|title=The Grand Prix Saboteurs|pages=30}} In 1919, the [[Ireland|Irish]] portrait painter, [[William Orpen]] became the official artist of the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]]. Orpen bought a Rolls-Royce car and hired Grover-Williams, who had returned to Paris, as his [[chauffeur]]. At the time, Orpen had a [[Mistress (lover)|mistress]] named [[Yvonne Aupicq]].Sometimes spelled Aubicque, see https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/7691212/The-WWI-copy-thats-worth-250000.html Aupicq and Grover-Williams became good friends and, after the collapse of Aupicq's relationship with Orpen, the pair were married in November 1929.{{cite book |last=Saward |authorlink=Joe Saward|title=The Grand Prix Saboteurs|pages=32}}{{cite book |last=Saward |authorlink=Joe Saward|title=The Grand Prix Saboteurs|pages=39}} ==Racing career== [[File:William Grover-Williams at the 1929 French Grand Prix (5).jpg|250px|thumb|right|William Grover-Williams in 1929 Le Mans, Grand Prix A.C.F. driving Bugatti Type 35]] By 1926, Grover-Williams had begun racing a [[Bugatti]] in races throughout France, using the alias, "W Williams",{{cite book | last = Higham | first = Peter | title = The Guinness Guide to International Motor Racing | publisher = Guinness Publishing | year = 1995 | pages = 200–208, 542 | isbn = 0-85112-642-1}} entering the ''Grand Prix de Provence'' at [[Circuit of Miramas|Miramas]] and the [[Monte Carlo Rally]]. In 1928, he won the [[French Grand Prix]], repeating in 1929. That same year, driving a Bugatti 35B, painted in what would become known as "[[British racing green]]", he won the inaugural [[Monaco Grand Prix]] beating the heavily favoured [[Mercedes-Benz|Mercedes]] of the great [[Germany|German]] driver, [[Rudolf Caracciola]]. Successful financially, Grover-Williams and his wife maintained a home in a fashionable district of Paris while owning a large house in the resort town of La Baule, [[Pays de la Loire]], on the [[Bay of Biscay]], which was home to one of the annual Grand Prix races. In 1931, he won the [[Belgian Grand Prix]] at [[Spa-Francorchamps]]. He also won the [[Grand Prix de la Baule]] in three consecutive years (1931 to 1933). Then his career waned and he was out of racing by the latter part of the 1930s. ==Second World War== Following the [[Nazi Germany|German]] occupation of [[French Republic|France]] in the [[World War II|Second World War]], Grover-Williams fled to [[England]] where he joined the [[Royal Army Service Corps]]. Due to his fluency in French and English, he was recruited into the [[Special Operations Executive]] (SOE) to foster the [[French Resistance]]. He recruited fellow racing driver [[Robert Benoist]] and together they worked in the [[Paris]] region to build up a successful circuit of operatives, forming sabotage cells and reception committees for Allied parachute operations. On 2 August 1943, Grover-Williams was arrested by the ''[[Sicherheitsdienst]]'' and underwent lengthy interrogation before being deported to Berlin and was then held prisoner in the [[Sachsenhausen concentration camp]]. ==Death== Grover-Williams was executed at Sachsenhausen in the spring of 1945, along with fellow SOE network leader [[Francis Suttill]].{{cite book |last=Saward |authorlink=Joe Saward|title=The Grand Prix Saboteurs|pages=317–318}}[http://www.grandprix.com/ns/ns18854.html "One of motor racing's greatest mysteries is solved"], MARCH 7 2007, grandprix.com There is a theory that Grover-Williams survived the war, and lived on under an assumed identity as "Georges Tambal" who allegedly lived with Grover-Williams's widow for many years, but there is no evidence for this whatsoever.[http://www.scotsman.com/scotland-on-sunday/sport/formula-one-uncovering-the-mystery-of-william-grover-williams-1-2321005 "Formula One: Uncovering the mystery of William Grover-Williams"], Richard Bath, Sunday 27 May 2012, The Scotsman on Sunday[http://8w.forix.com/rb-w-jpw.html "A different danger – three champions at war"], Richard Armstrong, 12 May 2002, forix.com ==Legacy and recognition== Grover-Williams is recorded on the [[Brookwood Memorial]] in [[Surrey]], England,{{Cite web |url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/2146381 |title=Casualty Details: GROVER-WILLIAMS, WILLIAM CHARLES FREDERICK |accessdate=4 January 2009 |work=[http://www.cwgc.org/default.asp Commonwealth War Graves Commission]}} and as one of the SOE agents who died for the liberation of France, he is listed on the [[Valençay SOE Memorial]]'s ''Roll of Honour'' in the French town of [[Valençay]]. Grover-Williams was recommended for an [[Order of the British Empire]] by the head of the SOE, [[Major-General (United Kingdom)|Major-General]] [[Colin Gubbins]], in September 1945, but when it became clear that he had died the honour was not awarded.{{cite book |last=Saward |authorlink=Joe Saward|title=The Grand Prix Saboteurs|pages=343}} ''[[The Saboteur (2009 video game)|The Saboteur]]'', a video game released in 2009, features an [[Irish people|Irish]] [[protagonist]] named Sean Devlin who is inspired by Grover-Williams.{{Cite web |url=http://uk.pc.ign.com/articles/779/779284p1.html |title=Saboteur Interview |accessdate=12 January 2009 |work=[[IGN]] |publisher= |date=9 April 2007 |deadurl=yes
